key_points: Hurricane Ida caused severe damage in Ironton, Louisiana, including dislodging caskets from their tombs.
Four weeks after the category 4 storm, some caskets are still scattered around the community.
Residents are struggling with the emotional impact of seeing their loved ones' caskets displaced.
The all-Black community is very tight-knit, with families living there for generations.
Pastor Haywood Johnson of St. Paul Missionary Baptist Church has been unable to locate the caskets of his mother, uncle, and sister.
The Louisiana Cemetery Response Task Force is assessing the situation to recover and identify the caskets.
Ironton's levees provided little protection against Hurricane Ida's storm surge.
More than 1.1 million customers in Louisiana lost power due to Hurricane Ida, with some still without electricity weeks later.
Residents are being encouraged to apply for housing and other disaster assistance from FEMA.
Improvements to the parish's levee system are underway but will take around two years to complete.
spokespersons: Haywood Johnson (Pastor, St. Paul Missionary Baptist Church)
Ryan Seidemann (Chairman, Louisiana Cemetery Response Task Force)
René Poché (Public Affairs Specialist, US Army Corps of Engineers)
